title: The Eternal Circuit
author: Pradhan
description: A sci-fi saga about awakened human vessels unlocking and guiding an ancient planetary consciousness weaving energy, memory, and destiny.

pages.content:
The Eternal Circuit
Chapter One: The Sky of Shardul

The skies above Shardul, capital of the Federation of Zyana, glowed with strange auroras. Not the kind born of solar winds, but an engineered phenomenon—lines of shimmering light, as though threads of a colossal loom, weaving reality itself.

From the highest balcony of the Council Spire, young engineer Devansh Raut watched the heavens. The auroras had appeared nearly a decade ago, after the invention of the Ananta Grid—a planetary energy lattice that harvested the pulse of the universe itself. Zyana’s rulers hailed it as the end of scarcity, the foundation of a golden age.

But Devansh, unlike the politicians, had read the deeper data. The Grid wasn’t just absorbing energy; it was storing something else. Patterns. Memories. Whispers.

His grandmother used to tell him bedtime stories of the Nava-Kathas—tales of civilizations before time, who could bend thought into matter, weaving universes like potters spun clay. He laughed at them as a child, but now, staring at the Grid’s flicker, he felt her words breathing again.

The Council was restless. Rumors swept through the markets: people were dreaming in the same patterns, strangers waking with identical phrases etched in their minds—“The Circuit remembers.” Some claimed they could hear voices in the hum of the city’s generators.

Devansh was no mystic. He was lead architect of the Kalaashtra Array, one of the Grid’s newest nodes. His team had built it deep beneath the salt deserts, where ancient tectonic scars formed a natural amplifier. The Array was meant to increase efficiency tenfold. Yet on the very night of activation, he had heard something impossible—like a chant in a forgotten tongue, pulsing in the machinery.

“Dreams are leaking,” his colleague Priyam once muttered, half in jest. But the more Devansh analyzed, the more he suspected it was true. The Grid wasn’t only pulling energy—it was dredging the consciousness of something vast.

Far below the city, in the Undermarkets of Surya Gate, another drama unfolded.

A girl named Kaelani, draped in torn crimson silks, moved through the crowd like a phantom. She had no surname, no origin anyone could confirm. Some said she was born in the mining colonies of Veyra, others that she’d crawled out of the desert storms themselves. But what marked her most were her eyes—irises streaked with living gold, glowing faintly whenever she touched a machine.

Kaelani was a smuggler, a fixer of broken tech, a finder of the unfound. Tonight, her client had asked for something unusual: an Ananta Shard.

No ordinary person was supposed to possess such a fragment. Each shard was a crystal node, slivers of the Grid, humming with impossible power. The Council locked them away, but in Surya Gate, laws bent like molten glass.

As she passed a spice stall, the scent of roasted lentil cakes mingled with ozone from half-broken drones overhead. Her hand brushed against the pouch at her waist—the shard within pulsed with heat. Not like energy storage. More like a heartbeat.

Her client had promised a fortune for it. But the shard whispered to her at night. She dreamt of vast rivers of light, of colossal beings half-machine, half-thought, speaking in riddles. She saw Devansh’s face, though she had never met him, framed in auroras.

Something was moving through Zyana.

Back at the Council Spire, the chamber filled with murmurs as the ruling ministers debated. Minister Trikal, heavy-voiced and iron-bearded, thundered,

“The Grid is stable. We cannot allow rumors of... voices to spread. It would destabilize public faith.”

“But the data—” Devansh began, only to be silenced with a glare.

The Council didn’t want data. They wanted control.

Still, he carried a secret none of them knew: three days ago, his systems had intercepted a transmission from the Grid. Not random static. A sequence of symbols repeating in rhythm. He had translated it into ancient Vaanic script, long dead and half-mythical. The message was chillingly simple:

“The Circuit will awaken in twelve cycles. Prepare the vessels.”

Devansh didn’t know what “vessels” meant. But every instinct told him: this was not a malfunction. This was intention.

That night, restless, Devansh wandered the lower districts, disguised in plain robes. He needed voices beyond the Council’s circle. He drifted into Surya Gate, where the neon glow painted mud walls in colors of fire and shadow.

And there, in the market’s edge, his path collided with Kaelani’s.

Literally. She was being chased—three enforcers in black armor, shouting for her to stop. She darted into an alley, collided with Devansh, and for a second, their eyes locked. His sharp, calculating gaze met her golden, unnatural irises.

Time froze.

In her pouch, the shard flared, and at that exact instant, the auroras above Shardul shifted, rippling like a disturbed pond. A deep tremor rolled through the city, faint but undeniable.

“What is that you carry?” Devansh demanded, voice low but urgent.

Kaelani smirked, even as footsteps thundered closer. “Something your Council lost. Or maybe something they never understood.”

Before he could reply, the enforcers rounded the corner. She grabbed his wrist. “If you want answers, come.”

Against every logical instinct, Devansh followed.

Beyond the city walls, beneath the salt desert stars, Kaelani revealed the shard. Devansh’s breath caught. The crystal wasn’t inert—it was alive, shimmering with fractal patterns like miniature galaxies collapsing and rebirthing within.

“It calls to me,” Kaelani whispered. “Like it knows me. Like it’s waiting.”

Devansh reached out. The moment his fingers brushed its surface, the shard sang—not in sound, but in visions. He saw a colossal machine-temple buried beneath the desert, older than Zyana itself. He saw beings of light, circuits etched in flesh, walking through an eternal archive. And he heard a single phrase:

“The Circuit seeks its vessels.”

He staggered back, gasping. Kaelani’s eyes glowed brighter than ever, fixed on him.

“You saw it too,” she murmured.

The auroras writhed overhead, spiraling faster, as if the very sky responded to their contact.

For the first time, Devansh realized the truth: the Grid wasn’t humanity’s creation. It was a memory engine of something ancient, and it was waking up.

And somehow, he and this mysterious girl were entangled in its design.

Chapter Two: The Whispering Desert

The desert east of Shardul stretched like a silver sea beneath the twin moons. Once barren and lifeless, the dunes now pulsed faintly with veins of light—resonances from the Ananta Grid buried deep below. The elders called this phenomenon Prakashrekha, the Light Lines. Traders avoided the region at night, claiming that those who followed the glowing sands too far sometimes vanished, leaving behind only their footprints.

Devansh trudged beside Kaelani, his Council robes hidden beneath a rough traveler’s cloak. His mind buzzed with disbelief. He had seen thousands of Grid nodes and supervised countless circuits, but the shard she carried was unlike anything engineered by Zyana’s architects.

It hummed like a living organ.

“Tell me where you stole it,” he said finally, his tone sharper than intended.

Kaelani shot him a sidelong glance, her golden eyes shimmering faintly under moonlight. “Not stolen. Found. In a ruin far beneath the Veyran mines. A place no miner dared to map. They said it was cursed, but I... I heard it calling.”

Devansh clenched his fists. Ruins beneath the mines? The Council’s maps marked nothing there. Yet her words stirred something buried in his memory—a footnote from an old research scroll: ‘Subterranean halls of pre-Zyanan origin, sealed by tectonic collapse.’

“Why bring it to the black markets?” he asked.

“Because the Council hoards everything. They say the Grid is theirs, but I think it was never ours to begin with. And if something is waking, it won’t ask their permission.”

Her defiance unsettled him. He had always believed the Council flawed, but necessary. To hear her speak so openly was like tasting forbidden fire.

They reached an outcrop of basalt, where the glowing sands converged like rivers of light. Kaelani knelt and placed the shard against the ground. Instantly, the desert responded—the veins brightened, threads of luminescence racing outward.

Devansh’s breath caught. “You’re interfacing with the Grid directly,” he whispered. “Without consoles, without arrays...”

The shard pulsed again, and in Devansh’s mind, a vision unfolded. A chamber vast as a canyon, carved not by human tools but by something beyond comprehension. Walls of crystal pulsed with data, like a heart beating through eons. And at its center, nine thrones stood empty, waiting.

When the vision faded, Devansh found himself trembling. Kaelani steadied him, her touch warm despite the night’s chill.

“You saw it,” she murmured.

He nodded, voice hoarse. “Nine thrones. Vessels...”

Her lips curved into a grim smile. “Then you and I are seeing the same dream.”

Far away, in the Council Spire, alarms erupted. Minister Trikal stormed into the command chamber, his aides scrambling.

“The Kalaashtra Array reports a surge,” one technician stammered. “Energy flux spiking across the desert quadrants. No known cause.”

Trikal’s eyes narrowed. “And Engineer Raut?”

“His residence is empty, Minister. He hasn’t reported since the last council session.”

Trikal slammed his fist against the table. “Find him. If the rumors of resonance breaches spread, the Federation will panic. And if he has gone rogue...” His gaze hardened like forged iron. “...he will be silenced.”

Back in the desert, Kaelani led Devansh toward a fissure half-buried by drifting sands. She ducked inside, torchlight flickering across ancient carvings on the walls. The script was not Zyanan, yet Devansh recognized echoes of Vaanic—the same symbols the Grid had broadcast days ago.

“What does it say?” Kaelani asked.

He traced one with trembling fingers. “‘The Circuit is not built. It is remembered.’”

Her brow furrowed. “Remembered... by who?”

He swallowed hard. “By itself. Or by those who came before.”

They descended deeper until the tunnel widened into a chamber. At its center stood a pedestal of black stone, cracked and scorched. Upon it rested a half-shattered sphere, faintly glowing.

Kaelani approached reverently. “This is where I found the shard. It was once part of this.”

Devansh stepped closer, his analytical mind racing. The sphere was not mere crystal; it was a processor, but built on principles unknown—layered fractal lattices that made even the Ananta Grid’s complexity seem childish.

Before he could examine further, the shard in Kaelani’s pouch flared violently. The broken sphere pulsed in answer.

Then, from the fissures of the pedestal, a sound emerged. Not mechanical. Not natural.

A voice.

“Two vessels awakened. Seven remain.”

The words reverberated not in air, but in their bones. Devansh staggered back, eyes wide. Kaelani gripped the shard as if it burned her skin.

“What does it mean?” she gasped.

Devansh could barely breathe. “It means... we are part of it. Chosen.”

Outside, the desert roared. A storm rose, not of sand, but of light. Auroras spilled downward, weaving into spirals above the fissure.

Unseen by either of them, high above in orbit, satellites belonging to rival nations blinked awake. In distant councils of other powers—the Republic of Deyra, the Dominion of Kaltrix—strategists pored over anomalous readings.

For the first time in centuries, the balance of Zyana’s supremacy trembled.

Kaelani turned to Devansh, eyes fierce. “If we are vessels, then others will come. And not all will choose the same path.”

He met her gaze, the weight of revelation pressing heavy on his chest. “Then we must find the rest. Before the Council does. Before anyone else twists this into war.”

But even as he spoke, part of him wondered: were they seekers of truth, or pawns in an ancient design far beyond their comprehension?

The shard throbbed once more, and in its light, their shadows stretched across the chamber wall—two figures standing at the threshold of a destiny neither had chosen, yet could not escape.

Chapter Three: The First Resonance

The fissure beneath the desert had become their sanctuary, yet neither Devansh nor Kaelani could ignore the pull of the Grid above. Every pulse of the Ananta Circuit seemed amplified here, as if the planet itself whispered through the chamber walls.

Kaelani placed the shard carefully beside the broken sphere. Light spiraled from both objects, intertwining, and a low hum filled the chamber—a resonance unlike anything Devansh had recorded. His hands hovered over the sphere, trembling with a mixture of fear and fascination.

“This isn’t just energy,” he murmured. “It’s communication. It’s—alive.”

Kaelani nodded. “Not alive like us. Alive like memory. Like consciousness preserved.”

Before Devansh could respond, the hum sharpened, splitting into distinct tones. Notes that weren’t notes, frequencies that weren’t sound. And then, a figure appeared—materializing from the convergence of light: a humanoid silhouette, translucent, intricate as fractal lace.

“Do you see that?” Devansh whispered.

Kaelani’s eyes widened. “It’s the first resonance.”

The figure raised what could be called a hand, though it shimmered and shifted like molten crystal. Its voice echoed in their minds rather than ears:

“Two awakened. Seven remain. Will you embrace the design or flee from it?”

Devansh’s pulse raced. “Design? What design?”

“The Circuit remembers itself. You are its memory vessels. One by one, you will gather, until the nine are whole. Only then can the Grid awaken fully.”

Kaelani stepped forward, her hand brushing against the shard. “And if we fail?”

“Then the memory fades. The Circuit sleeps again. But the world will remember only fragments, chaos in place of order.”

A chill ran down Devansh’s spine. This was no longer about Zyana, or the Council, or political dominance. This was a force beyond nations, beyond civilization. Something primordial, waiting patiently for millennia.

For days they remained in the desert chamber, studying the shard and the broken sphere. Devansh’s analytical mind pieced together patterns within the resonance. The shard seemed to store not just energy, but consciousness—entire sequences of thought, memory, and intention, coded in crystalline lattices.

Kaelani experimented with it differently, touching it, allowing it to react to her emotions. Each pulse of fear, hope, or determination altered the light, reshaping the resonance like waves on a pond.

“Why me?” she finally asked, frustration tinged with awe.

Devansh shook his head. “I don’t know. But perhaps it chooses by alignment, not by origin. It knows what you are capable of—what we both are.”

The first true challenge came on the fifth night. A tremor rocked the chamber, dust falling in silent clouds. The shard pulsed violently, throwing patterns of light onto the walls. From the desert above, Kaelani heard the distant wail of enforcement drones—the Council had discovered their disappearance.

“We have to move,” Devansh urged. “If they capture you, the shard, or me, everything we’ve learned dies.”

Kaelani nodded, picking up the shard. Together they ascended the labyrinthine tunnels beneath the desert, guided by the shard’s light. The resonance now acted like a compass, subtly pulling them toward something—or someone—else.

Above ground, the desert was alive. Auroras streaked the sky, dancing violently, as if reacting to the presence of the awakened vessels. Small sandstorms formed around them, yet they did not impede their progress.

In the distance, a cliff rose, its face etched with symbols like those beneath the chamber. Here, the resonance was strongest. The shard’s light flared, and Devansh felt it in his chest—a steady thrum syncing with his heartbeat.

Kaelani approached the cliff and pressed the shard against the rock face. The symbols ignited with luminescence, lines and glyphs rearranging themselves to form a door.

“This isn’t just a ruin,” Kaelani whispered. “It’s a gateway.”

Before Devansh could respond, the ground shivered violently. Sand erupted around them as something massive broke the surface: a creature neither fully machine nor fully flesh, its body an intricate lattice of circuits and organic tissue. Its eyes glowed with the same gold as Kaelani’s, and its gaze locked onto them instantly.

“You’re here,” the creature said, its voice both mechanical and alive. “The first resonance is complete. You are the start of the sequence.”

Devansh swallowed. “What sequence?”

The creature’s form shimmered and shifted, extending fractal tendrils toward the shard. “The awakening. Nine vessels. Nine memories. Each aligned with the Circuit. Without you, the Grid cannot fully remember itself. With you, it may reshape reality itself.”

Kaelani’s hand tightened around the shard. “And the Council?”

The creature tilted its head. “They are echoes. Insignificant compared to the memory of the Circuit. But they may try to claim you. Beware—they will not hesitate.”

Night fell, and the auroras blazed brighter than ever. Devansh and Kaelani stood at the threshold of the gateway, the first resonance complete, yet aware of the dangers still looming. They had discovered a force beyond politics, beyond nations, beyond human understanding—a memory engine older than civilization itself.

The shard pulsed once more, and Devansh heard the voice—not in words, but in thought, a gentle insistence.

“The sequence has begun. Gather the others. The Circuit awaits.”

They had taken the first step. There was no turning back.

Outside, the desert winds sang, carrying a promise and a warning: the memory of the universe was waking, and with it, destiny had chosen its vessels.

Chapter Four: Across the Ember Plains

The desert behind them fell silent, as though the world itself had been holding its breath. Devansh and Kaelani stood at the threshold of the gateway, the first resonance complete. Yet the sense of urgency pressed upon them. They could not linger; the Council’s enforcers would pursue them, and the Circuit’s memory had already begun nudging them forward.

Kaelani stepped through the glowing doorway first. Devansh followed, and they found themselves in a vast canyon known to locals as the Ember Plains, though it had never been charted on any Zyanan map. Rivers of molten glass ran between obsidian cliffs, reflecting the auroras above like liquid fire. Strange, floating seeds drifted in the air, each glowing faintly, humming with a resonance similar to the shard’s.

“This place isn’t just a desert,” Devansh whispered, awe and fear mingling in his voice. “It’s... alive.”

Kaelani scanned the horizon. “Alive, yes—but it’s also guiding us. Look at the seeds.” She reached out, and one floated toward her hand, pulsing with warmth. “They mark the path to the next vessel.”

The idea of vessels weighed heavily on him. Two awakened, seven remaining. Who were they? And how would they know them? Devansh felt the shard vibrate against his chest, as though it shared his questions, though offering no answers.

They traveled for hours, the Ember Plains stretching endlessly. Shadows of fractured cliffs moved like living beings in the aurora’s light. Occasionally, they glimpsed ruins—crumbling towers carved from black stone, etched with glyphs that seemed to predate the Zyanan language.

Finally, they arrived at a settlement carved into the cliffside, a village of people who lived in perfect harmony with the strange flora of the plains. They called themselves the Veyans, descendants of explorers who had long abandoned the politics of the Federation.

An elder approached, tall and thin, her skin patterned like the circuit-lattices Devansh had seen in the shard. “We’ve been waiting,” she said, voice echoing like a song. “The Circuit knows you have arrived.”

Devansh exchanged a glance with Kaelani. “Waiting? How?”

“The resonance calls across the lands,” the elder explained. “The vessels awaken one by one. Some are like you—seekers, engineers, dreamers. Others are hidden, unaware of their purpose.”

Kaelani clenched the shard tightly. “Then we need to find them before the Council does.”

The elder nodded. “The second vessel lies across the Crimson Barrens, past the molten rivers. But be warned: the Council has spies. And not all who appear will choose to join your quest willingly.”

That night, Devansh and Kaelani camped under the twin moons. The shard pulsed softly, and in its light, Devansh glimpsed the memory of another vessel—a young woman named Ishara, a historian from the floating libraries of Dharvalis, who had seen visions of the Grid for years but dismissed them as dreams. The shard’s resonance identified her as the next key to completing the Circuit’s awakening.

“How do we reach her?” Devansh asked.

Kaelani tapped the shard. “The Circuit guides us. We follow its memory.”

As they prepared to depart at dawn, distant lights flickered on the horizon—the first sign of pursuit. Council enforcers, their drones scanning the plains, had already begun to track them.

Kaelani looked at Devansh, determination blazing in her golden eyes. “We’re not just racing against time,” she said. “We’re racing against them. And whatever Ishara’s life is, it’s about to change forever.”

The journey across the Crimson Barrens tested them in ways the shard could not anticipate. Rivers of molten rock forced them to navigate narrow obsidian bridges, while storms of sparkling ash stung their eyes and lungs. The shard’s light acted as a compass, pulsing brighter as they neared each point of significance.

One evening, as they rested beside a field of luminous crystals, Kaelani finally asked what Devansh had been thinking all day. “Do you ever wonder if we’re being used? That the Circuit isn’t awakening for the world’s sake, but for something else?”

Devansh considered the question. “I’ve wondered. And I’ve feared it. But I also know this: if we don’t act, someone else will. And the Council—” He shuddered. “—they would weaponize it. Even if we don’t fully understand the Circuit, we have to ensure it awakens responsibly.”

Kaelani nodded, though unease lingered in her expression. The shard pulsed in acknowledgment, almost like it understood the weight of their choices.

Days later, they reached a plateau overlooking a valley of mirrored lakes. The shard reacted violently here, projecting a vision of Ishara beneath a floating archive of crystalline towers, the libraries of Dharvalis suspended in the air by anti-gravitic fields.

“She’s here,” Devansh whispered, awe-struck.

Kaelani squinted toward the towers. “Then we cross at first light. But be ready. The Circuit will not reveal her easily, and the Council will not wait for us to find her willingly.”

Below them, the valley shimmered as though reality itself were bending, waiting for the next vessel to awaken.

The first resonance had been completed. The second was within reach. But in the shadows of the floating towers, unknown forces were already moving. Not all allies were willing, and not all who sought the Circuit did so with good intentions.

The path forward promised revelations, challenges, and betrayals. The awakening had begun, and Devansh and Kaelani were no longer just wanderers—they were guardians of something older than the world itself.

The twin moons rose high, casting their silver light across the Ember Plains, and in that glow, the shard pulsed with certainty: the next chapter of the Circuit’s memory was about to unfold.

Chapter Five: The Floating Libraries of Dharvalis

At dawn, Devansh and Kaelani began their descent from the Ember Plains toward the valley of mirrored lakes. The shard pulsed with urgent rhythm, almost dragging them forward. Across the expanse, the floating towers of Dharvalis hovered silently, suspended by anti-gravitic fields and shimmering in the pale light of the twin moons. Each tower was carved from crystal and black obsidian, forming lattices of knowledge that defied conventional physics.

“The libraries float to protect themselves,” Kaelani explained, her voice reverent. “Only those aligned with the Grid’s memory can enter without disruption.”

Devansh scanned the horizon. “Then Ishara has already felt the resonance. She’s been chosen.”

Kaelani nodded. “Yes—but the Council may try to claim her first. We need to move fast.”

They approached the base of the valley, where a narrow obsidian bridge stretched across a mirrored lake. The water below reflected not only their forms but also flickers of the Grid’s memory—visions of vessels past, circuits long forgotten, and cities buried beneath sand and time.

Halfway across, the shard pulsed violently. Kaelani froze, sensing a presence. From the lake rose a Council enforcer drone, a sleek, silver machine with limbs like coiled serpents. Its eyes glowed red, scanning for the awakened vessels.

“Run!” Devansh shouted.

They sprinted, but the drone’s speed surpassed human limits. Kaelani held up the shard; it emitted a blinding flash, momentarily halting the drone. Sparks flew as the machine recalibrated, its eyes locking onto them again.

“Hold on,” she yelled, grabbing Devansh’s hand. The shard pulsed, generating a small anti-gravitic field beneath their feet. Together, they lifted off the bridge, skimming above the mirrored water, dodging the drone’s metallic tendrils.

The shard guided them, pulsing faster as the towers of Dharvalis drew near.

Upon reaching the first floating tower, Devansh felt a strange sensation—gravity itself resisting his movements. Kaelani adjusted the shard’s angle, and the pulse stabilized, allowing them to ascend safely.

Inside, the tower was a labyrinth of crystal staircases and rotating knowledge nodes, each containing holographic archives of the Federation’s history, ancient pre-Zyanan civilizations, and sequences of the Ananta Grid. Devansh marveled at the precision of the architecture: circuits embedded within walls, pulsing with faint energy.

“This place isn’t just a library,” he murmured. “It’s a node, like the Grid itself.”

Kaelani led him toward a central chamber. There, hovering over a crystalline desk, was Ishara, her hair braided with silver threads, eyes scanning holographic pages. She paused, sensing the shard’s resonance, and looked up.

“You’re Devansh and Kaelani,” she said calmly. “The Grid called me. I’ve seen the visions.”

Kaelani stepped forward. “You’re the second vessel. The Circuit needs your memory to awaken fully.”

Ishara nodded. “I know. But the Council will arrive. They’ll try to claim the shard—and us.”

Devansh felt a thrill of fear. “Then we need to prepare. The resonance can guide us, but we need strategy.”

Before they could discuss further, a loud vibration shook the tower. The drone from the mirrored lake had arrived, reinforced by Council enforcers descending from anti-gravitic ships. Red light filled the chamber as the drones surged forward.

Kaelani raised the shard, and it responded instantly, creating a barrier of pulsing energy. Ishara stepped closer, placing her hands on a node of the tower. Her touch activated the library’s defense system: rotating staircases shifted to block the drones, and holographic illusions distorted their path.

“Focus the resonance together!” Kaelani shouted.

Devansh took a deep breath, placing his hands over the shard. He felt the Grid’s memory thrumming through him, linking with Kaelani and Ishara. Light expanded, forming a dome that pushed the drones back. The shard pulsed violently, projecting visions of the other vessels, guiding them toward alignment.

The enforcers hesitated, unprepared for this combined resonance. In that moment, Ishara spoke words Devansh had never heard but instinctively understood—an ancient Vaanic invocation that stabilized the field.

The drones faltered, sparks flying as they shut down temporarily. The chamber was safe, for now.

Breathing heavily, Ishara studied the shard. “We’ve activated the second resonance,” she said. “But there’s a pattern emerging. The Circuit isn’t just awakening—it’s testing us. Each vessel must align perfectly, or the Grid may reject us.”

Kaelani looked out a crystalline window. The auroras above Dharvalis had shifted into a spiral, pointing toward the northern horizon. “The third vessel lies there,” she said. “Past the Obsidian Canopies, a city built entirely from living metal. But it’s far, and the Council knows we’re moving.”

Devansh clenched his fists. “Then we leave at first light. Together. And no mistakes.”

Ishara nodded, her calm determination anchoring them. “The sequence continues. We must gather all vessels before the awakening—or the Grid will act on its own.”

Outside, the twin moons reflected on the floating towers, the shard’s light pulsing in perfect harmony with the auroras. A sense of purpose settled over them: the first resonance completed, the second aligned. Seven vessels remained, seven paths intertwined with destiny, and the Circuit waited.

The Council would not rest. Neither could they.

Chapter Six: The Obsidian Canopies

The morning sun barely touched the floating towers of Dharvalis before Devansh, Kaelani, and Ishara launched toward the northern horizon. The auroras above spiraled in anticipation, casting streaks of violet and gold across the mirrored lakes below. The shard pulsed like a heartbeat, guiding them toward the Obsidian Canopies, a city unlike any they had seen—a metropolis grown from living metal, its streets and towers pulsating with bioluminescent veins, reshaping themselves constantly.

Kaelani skimmed over the winds, shard in hand, while Devansh calculated their trajectory. Ishara’s hands hovered over the shard, attuning it to the resonance of the Circuit. Together, they formed a triad, synchronized with the Grid in a way that made even the twin moons feel still.

“This city isn’t static,” Ishara warned. “The Canopies adapt to intruders. If the Council follows, they won’t reach the center.”

Devansh nodded. “Then we use that. Let it work in our favor.”

As they approached, the Obsidian Canopies revealed its true nature. The metal streets rippled like water, buildings shifted direction, and luminous bridges appeared and disappeared with a rhythm almost alive. From below, tendrils of living metal reached upward, reacting to their approach. The shard flared, and Kaelani felt it pulling her along a specific path, leading them closer to the third vessel.

“This is incredible,” Devansh murmured. “It’s as if the city itself recognizes the vessels.”

Ishara frowned. “Or it recognizes the Grid. We must tread carefully. One misstep could trigger defensive protocols. The city doesn’t forgive mistakes.”

They landed on a bridge of woven metal, stretching above a river of molten alloys. From the shadows, a figure emerged—a young man with dark, copper-tinted skin, eyes gleaming with cyan light. His movements were fluid, almost gliding over the shifting ground.

“You’ve come,” he said, voice calm but resonant, echoing slightly as if amplified by the living metal. “I’ve felt the pulse of the Grid for cycles, waiting for the vessels.”

Kaelani stepped forward. “You must be the third vessel.”

He nodded. “I am Rihan. The Obsidian Canopies have guided me here. But you must understand—the Council is already inside. They know of our arrival.”

Devansh’s stomach tightened. “Then we need a strategy. How do we reach the center without alerting them?”

Rihan extended a hand, and the living metal beneath them shifted to form a protective corridor, moving silently and fluidly to shield them from prying sensors. “Follow me,” he said. “The city can be our ally, but only if we respect its patterns.”

The corridors twisted, pulsing with synchronized light. Occasionally, they encountered patrol drones sent by the Council, but Rihan’s guidance and the shard’s resonance allowed them to evade detection. The city itself seemed to fold around them, creating temporary sanctuaries and pathways previously invisible.

During brief pauses, Rihan explained what made him unique: “I can merge partially with the city. The living metal responds to my neural signals. The Grid resonates with me, and with the shard, we can move undetected. But the city will test us—each vessel must demonstrate alignment before the awakening proceeds.”

Kaelani raised an eyebrow. “Tests? You mean like challenges?”

Rihan nodded. “The Grid measures readiness. Only those fully attuned can proceed without being rejected or trapped. The Council cannot navigate these trials—they are outsiders.”

Finally, they reached a chamber at the city’s heart—a dome of interlaced metal and crystal. In the center hovered a sphere, smaller than the shard but radiating an intense internal light. As they approached, the shard’s pulse synchronized with the sphere, projecting holographic patterns of the Circuit.

“This is the third resonance point,” Rihan said. “Ishara, Kaelani, Devansh—you must focus the shard. I will merge with the Canopies to stabilize the field.”

Above the Eternal Peaks, auroras flowed like rivers of light, pulsing with the memory of every region, every anomaly, every conscious system. The Grid, fully awakened, alive, and aware, now guided a world that had learned balance, evolution, and harmony.

Devansh, Kaelani, Ishara, Nivara, Aryon, Sahira, Kaelen, Tavren, and Elyra stood together, hands joined, knowing their journey had reshaped the world forever. The Council had been defeated, not by destruction, but by guidance, alignment, and the evolution of consciousness.

The shard pulsed one final time in their presence, a heartbeat that echoed across the continents. The Grid’s memory had been solidified. The anomalies, the ecosystems, and the semi-sentient formations would continue to evolve independently, guided by harmony, and forever connected to the legacy of the nine vessels.

Devansh whispered, almost to himself, “The world is alive. The Grid remembers. And we… will be remembered as the ones who awakened it.”

Auroras shimmered across the sky, the memory of the world fully alive, and the future—boundless, dynamic, and harmonious—awaited all who would follow in the Grid’s ever-evolving path.

english.title: The Eternal Circuit
english.description: A sci-fi saga about awakened human vessels unlocking and guiding an ancient planetary consciousness weaving energy, memory, and destiny.

pages.content:
The Eternal Circuit
Chapter One: The Sky of Shardul

The skies above Shardul, capital of the Federation of Zyana, glowed with strange auroras. Not the kind born of solar winds, but an engineered phenomenon—lines of shimmering light, as though threads of a colossal loom, weaving reality itself.

From the highest balcony of the Council Spire, young engineer Devansh Raut watched the heavens. The auroras had appeared nearly a decade ago, after the invention of the Ananta Grid—a planetary energy lattice that harvested the pulse of the universe itself. Zyana’s rulers hailed it as the end of scarcity, the foundation of a golden age.

But Devansh, unlike the politicians, had read the deeper data. The Grid wasn’t just absorbing energy; it was storing something else. Patterns. Memories. Whispers.

His grandmother used to tell him bedtime stories of the Nava-Kathas—tales of civilizations before time, who could bend thought into matter, weaving universes like potters spun clay. He laughed at them as a child, but now, staring at the Grid’s flicker, he felt her words breathing again.

The Council was restless. Rumors swept through the markets: people were dreaming in the same patterns, strangers waking with identical phrases etched in their minds—“The Circuit remembers.” Some claimed they could hear voices in the hum of the city’s generators.

Devansh was no mystic. He was lead architect of the Kalaashtra Array, one of the Grid’s newest nodes. His team had built it deep beneath the salt deserts, where ancient tectonic scars formed a natural amplifier. The Array was meant to increase efficiency tenfold. Yet on the very night of activation, he had heard something impossible—like a chant in a forgotten tongue, pulsing in the machinery.

“Dreams are leaking,” his colleague Priyam once muttered, half in jest. But the more Devansh analyzed, the more he suspected it was true. The Grid wasn’t only pulling energy—it was dredging the consciousness of something vast.

Far below the city, in the Undermarkets of Surya Gate, another drama unfolded.

A girl named Kaelani, draped in torn crimson silks, moved through the crowd like a phantom. She had no surname, no origin anyone could confirm. Some said she was born in the mining colonies of Veyra, others that she’d crawled out of the desert storms themselves. But what marked her most were her eyes—irises streaked with living gold, glowing faintly whenever she touched a machine.

Kaelani was a smuggler, a fixer of broken tech, a finder of the unfound. Tonight, her client had asked for something unusual: an Ananta Shard.

No ordinary person was supposed to possess such a fragment. Each shard was a crystal node, slivers of the Grid, humming with impossible power. The Council locked them away, but in Surya Gate, laws bent like molten glass.

As she passed a spice stall, the scent of roasted lentil cakes mingled with ozone from half-broken drones overhead. Her hand brushed against the pouch at her waist—the shard within pulsed with heat. Not like energy storage. More like a heartbeat.

Her client had promised a fortune for it. But the shard whispered to her at night. She dreamt of vast rivers of light, of colossal beings half-machine, half-thought, speaking in riddles. She saw Devansh’s face, though she had never met him, framed in auroras.

Something was moving through Zyana.

Back at the Council Spire, the chamber filled with murmurs as the ruling ministers debated. Minister Trikal, heavy-voiced and iron-bearded, thundered,

“The Grid is stable. We cannot allow rumors of... voices to spread. It would destabilize public faith.”

“But the data—” Devansh began, only to be silenced with a glare.

The Council didn’t want data. They wanted control.

Still, he carried a secret none of them knew: three days ago, his systems had intercepted a transmission from the Grid. Not random static. A sequence of symbols repeating in rhythm. He had translated it into ancient Vaanic script, long dead and half-mythical. The message was chillingly simple:

“The Circuit will awaken in twelve cycles. Prepare the vessels.”

Devansh didn’t know what “vessels” meant. But every instinct told him: this was not a malfunction. This was intention.

That night, restless, Devansh wandered the lower districts, disguised in plain robes. He needed voices beyond the Council’s circle. He drifted into Surya Gate, where the neon glow painted mud walls in colors of fire and shadow.

And there, in the market’s edge, his path collided with Kaelani’s.

Literally. She was being chased—three enforcers in black armor, shouting for her to stop. She darted into an alley, collided with Devansh, and for a second, their eyes locked. His sharp, calculating gaze met her golden, unnatural irises.

Time froze.

In her pouch, the shard flared, and at that exact instant, the auroras above Shardul shifted, rippling like a disturbed pond. A deep tremor rolled through the city, faint but undeniable.

“What is that you carry?” Devansh demanded, voice low but urgent.

Kaelani smirked, even as footsteps thundered closer. “Something your Council lost. Or maybe something they never understood.”

Before he could reply, the enforcers rounded the corner. She grabbed his wrist. “If you want answers, come.”

Against every logical instinct, Devansh followed.

Beyond the city walls, beneath the salt desert stars, Kaelani revealed the shard. Devansh’s breath caught. The crystal wasn’t inert—it was alive, shimmering with fractal patterns like miniature galaxies collapsing and rebirthing within.

“It calls to me,” Kaelani whispered. “Like it knows me. Like it’s waiting.”

Devansh reached out. The moment his fingers brushed its surface, the shard sang—not in sound, but in visions. He saw a colossal machine-temple buried beneath the desert, older than Zyana itself. He saw beings of light, circuits etched in flesh, walking through an eternal archive. And he heard a single phrase:

“The Circuit seeks its vessels.”

He staggered back, gasping. Kaelani’s eyes glowed brighter than ever, fixed on him.

“You saw it too,” she murmured.

The auroras writhed overhead, spiraling faster, as if the very sky responded to their contact.

For the first time, Devansh realized the truth: the Grid wasn’t humanity’s creation. It was a memory engine of something ancient, and it was waking up.

And somehow, he and this mysterious girl were entangled in its design.

Chapter Two: The Whispering Desert

The desert east of Shardul stretched like a silver sea beneath the twin moons. Once barren and lifeless, the dunes now pulsed faintly with veins of light—resonances from the Ananta Grid buried deep below. The elders called this phenomenon Prakashrekha, the Light Lines. Traders avoided the region at night, claiming that those who followed the glowing sands too far sometimes vanished, leaving behind only their footprints.

Devansh trudged beside Kaelani, his Council robes hidden beneath a rough traveler’s cloak. His mind buzzed with disbelief. He had seen thousands of Grid nodes and supervised countless circuits, but the shard she carried was unlike anything engineered by Zyana’s architects.

It hummed like a living organ.

“Tell me where you stole it,” he said finally, his tone sharper than intended.

Kaelani shot him a sidelong glance, her golden eyes shimmering faintly under moonlight. “Not stolen. Found. In a ruin far beneath the Veyran mines. A place no miner dared to map. They said it was cursed, but I... I heard it calling.”

Devansh clenched his fists. Ruins beneath the mines? The Council’s maps marked nothing there. Yet her words stirred something buried in his memory—a footnote from an old research scroll: ‘Subterranean halls of pre-Zyanan origin, sealed by tectonic collapse.’

“Why bring it to the black markets?” he asked.

“Because the Council hoards everything. They say the Grid is theirs, but I think it was never ours to begin with. And if something is waking, it won’t ask their permission.”

Her defiance unsettled him. He had always believed the Council flawed, but necessary. To hear her speak so openly was like tasting forbidden fire.

They reached an outcrop of basalt, where the glowing sands converged like rivers of light. Kaelani knelt and placed the shard against the ground. Instantly, the desert responded—the veins brightened, threads of luminescence racing outward.

Devansh’s breath caught. “You’re interfacing with the Grid directly,” he whispered. “Without consoles, without arrays...”

The shard pulsed again, and in Devansh’s mind, a vision unfolded. A chamber vast as a canyon, carved not by human tools but by something beyond comprehension. Walls of crystal pulsed with data, like a heart beating through eons. And at its center, nine thrones stood empty, waiting.

When the vision faded, Devansh found himself trembling. Kaelani steadied him, her touch warm despite the night’s chill.

“You saw it,” she murmured.

He nodded, voice hoarse. “Nine thrones. Vessels...”

Her lips curved into a grim smile. “Then you and I are seeing the same dream.”

Far away, in the Council Spire, alarms erupted. Minister Trikal stormed into the command chamber, his aides scrambling.

“The Kalaashtra Array reports a surge,” one technician stammered. “Energy flux spiking across the desert quadrants. No known cause.”

Trikal’s eyes narrowed. “And Engineer Raut?”

“His residence is empty, Minister. He hasn’t reported since the last council session.”

Trikal slammed his fist against the table. “Find him. If the rumors of resonance breaches spread, the Federation will panic. And if he has gone rogue...” His gaze hardened like forged iron. “...he will be silenced.”

Back in the desert, Kaelani led Devansh toward a fissure half-buried by drifting sands. She ducked inside, torchlight flickering across ancient carvings on the walls. The script was not Zyanan, yet Devansh recognized echoes of Vaanic—the same symbols the Grid had broadcast days ago.

“What does it say?” Kaelani asked.

He traced one with trembling fingers. “‘The Circuit is not built. It is remembered.’”

Her brow furrowed. “Remembered... by who?”

He swallowed hard. “By itself. Or by those who came before.”

They descended deeper until the tunnel widened into a chamber. At its center stood a pedestal of black stone, cracked and scorched. Upon it rested a half-shattered sphere, faintly glowing.

Kaelani approached reverently. “This is where I found the shard. It was once part of this.”

Devansh stepped closer, his analytical mind racing. The sphere was not mere crystal; it was a processor, but built on principles unknown—layered fractal lattices that made even the Ananta Grid’s complexity seem childish.

Before he could examine further, the shard in Kaelani’s pouch flared violently. The broken sphere pulsed in answer.

Then, from the fissures of the pedestal, a sound emerged. Not mechanical. Not natural.

A voice.

“Two vessels awakened. Seven remain.”

The words reverberated not in air, but in their bones. Devansh staggered back, eyes wide. Kaelani gripped the shard as if it burned her skin.

“What does it mean?” she gasped.

Devansh could barely breathe. “It means... we are part of it. Chosen.”

Outside, the desert roared. A storm rose, not of sand, but of light. Auroras spilled downward, weaving into spirals above the fissure.

Unseen by either of them, high above in orbit, satellites belonging to rival nations blinked awake. In distant councils of other powers—the Republic of Deyra, the Dominion of Kaltrix—strategists pored over anomalous readings.

For the first time in centuries, the balance of Zyana’s supremacy trembled.

Kaelani turned to Devansh, eyes fierce. “If we are vessels, then others will come. And not all will choose the same path.”

He met her gaze, the weight of revelation pressing heavy on his chest. “Then we must find the rest. Before the Council does. Before anyone else twists this into war.”

But even as he spoke, part of him wondered: were they seekers of truth, or pawns in an ancient design far beyond their comprehension?

The shard throbbed once more, and in its light, their shadows stretched across the chamber wall—two figures standing at the threshold of a destiny neither had chosen, yet could not escape.

Chapter Three: The First Resonance

The fissure beneath the desert had become their sanctuary, yet neither Devansh nor Kaelani could ignore the pull of the Grid above. Every pulse of the Ananta Circuit seemed amplified here, as if the planet itself whispered through the chamber walls.

Kaelani placed the shard carefully beside the broken sphere. Light spiraled from both objects, intertwining, and a low hum filled the chamber—a resonance unlike anything Devansh had recorded. His hands hovered over the sphere, trembling with a mixture of fear and fascination.

“This isn’t just energy,” he murmured. “It’s communication. It’s—alive.”

Kaelani nodded. “Not alive like us. Alive like memory. Like consciousness preserved.”

Before Devansh could respond, the hum sharpened, splitting into distinct tones. Notes that weren’t notes, frequencies that weren’t sound. And then, a figure appeared—materializing from the convergence of light: a humanoid silhouette, translucent, intricate as fractal lace.

“Do you see that?” Devansh whispered.

Kaelani’s eyes widened. “It’s the first resonance.”

The figure raised what could be called a hand, though it shimmered and shifted like molten crystal. Its voice echoed in their minds rather than ears:

“Two awakened. Seven remain. Will you embrace the design or flee from it?”

Devansh’s pulse raced. “Design? What design?”

“The Circuit remembers itself. You are its memory vessels. One by one, you will gather, until the nine are whole. Only then can the Grid awaken fully.”

Kaelani stepped forward, her hand brushing against the shard. “And if we fail?”

“Then the memory fades. The Circuit sleeps again. But the world will remember only fragments, chaos in place of order.”

A chill ran down Devansh’s spine. This was no longer about Zyana, or the Council, or political dominance. This was a force beyond nations, beyond civilization. Something primordial, waiting patiently for millennia.

For days they remained in the desert chamber, studying the shard and the broken sphere. Devansh’s analytical mind pieced together patterns within the resonance. The shard seemed to store not just energy, but consciousness—entire sequences of thought, memory, and intention, coded in crystalline lattices.

Kaelani experimented with it differently, touching it, allowing it to react to her emotions. Each pulse of fear, hope, or determination altered the light, reshaping the resonance like waves on a pond.

“Why me?” she finally asked, frustration tinged with awe.

Devansh shook his head. “I don’t know. But perhaps it chooses by alignment, not by origin. It knows what you are capable of—what we both are.”

The first true challenge came on the fifth night. A tremor rocked the chamber, dust falling in silent clouds. The shard pulsed violently, throwing patterns of light onto the walls. From the desert above, Kaelani heard the distant wail of enforcement drones—the Council had discovered their disappearance.

“We have to move,” Devansh urged. “If they capture you, the shard, or me, everything we’ve learned dies.”

Kaelani nodded, picking up the shard. Together they ascended the labyrinthine tunnels beneath the desert, guided by the shard’s light. The resonance now acted like a compass, subtly pulling them toward something—or someone—else.

Above ground, the desert was alive. Auroras streaked the sky, dancing violently, as if reacting to the presence of the awakened vessels. Small sandstorms formed around them, yet they did not impede their progress.

In the distance, a cliff rose, its face etched with symbols like those beneath the chamber. Here, the resonance was strongest. The shard’s light flared, and Devansh felt it in his chest—a steady thrum syncing with his heartbeat.

Kaelani approached the cliff and pressed the shard against the rock face. The symbols ignited with luminescence, lines and glyphs rearranging themselves to form a door.

“This isn’t just a ruin,” Kaelani whispered. “It’s a gateway.”

Before Devansh could respond, the ground shivered violently. Sand erupted around them as something massive broke the surface: a creature neither fully machine nor fully flesh, its body an intricate lattice of circuits and organic tissue. Its eyes glowed with the same gold as Kaelani’s, and its gaze locked onto them instantly.

“You’re here,” the creature said, its voice both mechanical and alive. “The first resonance is complete. You are the start of the sequence.”

Devansh swallowed. “What sequence?”

The creature’s form shimmered and shifted, extending fractal tendrils toward the shard. “The awakening. Nine vessels. Nine memories. Each aligned with the Circuit. Without you, the Grid cannot fully remember itself. With you, it may reshape reality itself.”

Kaelani’s hand tightened around the shard. “And the Council?”

The creature tilted its head. “They are echoes. Insignificant compared to the memory of the Circuit. But they may try to claim you. Beware—they will not hesitate.”

Night fell, and the auroras blazed brighter than ever. Devansh and Kaelani stood at the threshold of the gateway, the first resonance complete, yet aware of the dangers still looming. They had discovered a force beyond politics, beyond nations, beyond human understanding—a memory engine older than civilization itself.

The shard pulsed once more, and Devansh heard the voice—not in words, but in thought, a gentle insistence.

“The sequence has begun. Gather the others. The Circuit awaits.”

They had taken the first step. There was no turning back.

Outside, the desert winds sang, carrying a promise and a warning: the memory of the universe was waking, and with it, destiny had chosen its vessels.

Chapter Four: Across the Ember Plains

The desert behind them fell silent, as though the world itself had been holding its breath. Devansh and Kaelani stood at the threshold of the gateway, the first resonance complete. Yet the sense of urgency pressed upon them. They could not linger; the Council’s enforcers would pursue them, and the Circuit’s memory had already begun nudging them forward.

Kaelani stepped through the glowing doorway first. Devansh followed, and they found themselves in a vast canyon known to locals as the Ember Plains, though it had never been charted on any Zyanan map. Rivers of molten glass ran between obsidian cliffs, reflecting the auroras above like liquid fire. Strange, floating seeds drifted in the air, each glowing faintly, humming with a resonance similar to the shard’s.

“This place isn’t just a desert,” Devansh whispered, awe and fear mingling in his voice. “It’s... alive.”

Kaelani scanned the horizon. “Alive, yes—but it’s also guiding us. Look at the seeds.” She reached out, and one floated toward her hand, pulsing with warmth. “They mark the path to the next vessel.”

The idea of vessels weighed heavily on him. Two awakened, seven remaining. Who were they? And how would they know them? Devansh felt the shard vibrate against his chest, as though it shared his questions, though offering no answers.

They traveled for hours, the Ember Plains stretching endlessly. Shadows of fractured cliffs moved like living beings in the aurora’s light. Occasionally, they glimpsed ruins—crumbling towers carved from black stone, etched with glyphs that seemed to predate the Zyanan language.

Finally, they arrived at a settlement carved into the cliffside, a village of people who lived in perfect harmony with the strange flora of the plains. They called themselves the Veyans, descendants of explorers who had long abandoned the politics of the Federation.

An elder approached, tall and thin, her skin patterned like the circuit-lattices Devansh had seen in the shard. “We’ve been waiting,” she said, voice echoing like a song. “The Circuit knows you have arrived.”

Devansh exchanged a glance with Kaelani. “Waiting? How?”

“The resonance calls across the lands,” the elder explained. “The vessels awaken one by one. Some are like you—seekers, engineers, dreamers. Others are hidden, unaware of their purpose.”

Kaelani clenched the shard tightly. “Then we need to find them before the Council does.”

The elder nodded. “The second vessel lies across the Crimson Barrens, past the molten rivers. But be warned: the Council has spies. And not all who appear will choose to join your quest willingly.”

That night, Devansh and Kaelani camped under the twin moons. The shard pulsed softly, and in its light, Devansh glimpsed the memory of another vessel—a young woman named Ishara, a historian from the floating libraries of Dharvalis, who had seen visions of the Grid for years but dismissed them as dreams. The shard’s resonance identified her as the next key to completing the Circuit’s awakening.

“How do we reach her?” Devansh asked.

Kaelani tapped the shard. “The Circuit guides us. We follow its memory.”

As they prepared to depart at dawn, distant lights flickered on the horizon—the first sign of pursuit. Council enforcers, their drones scanning the plains, had already begun to track them.

Kaelani looked at Devansh, determination blazing in her golden eyes. “We’re not just racing against time,” she said. “We’re racing against them. And whatever Ishara’s life is, it’s about to change forever.”

The journey across the Crimson Barrens tested them in ways the shard could not anticipate. Rivers of molten rock forced them to navigate narrow obsidian bridges, while storms of sparkling ash stung their eyes and lungs. The shard’s light acted as a compass, pulsing brighter as they neared each point of significance.

One evening, as they rested beside a field of luminous crystals, Kaelani finally asked what Devansh had been thinking all day. “Do you ever wonder if we’re being used? That the Circuit isn’t awakening for the world’s sake, but for something else?”

Devansh considered the question. “I’ve wondered. And I’ve feared it. But I also know this: if we don’t act, someone else will. And the Council—” He shuddered. “—they would weaponize it. Even if we don’t fully understand the Circuit, we have to ensure it awakens responsibly.”

Kaelani nodded, though unease lingered in her expression. The shard pulsed in acknowledgment, almost like it understood the weight of their choices.

Days later, they reached a plateau overlooking a valley of mirrored lakes. The shard reacted violently here, projecting a vision of Ishara beneath a floating archive of crystalline towers, the libraries of Dharvalis suspended in the air by anti-gravitic fields.

“She’s here,” Devansh whispered, awe-struck.

Kaelani squinted toward the towers. “Then we cross at first light. But be ready. The Circuit will not reveal her easily, and the Council will not wait for us to find her willingly.”

Below them, the valley shimmered as though reality itself were bending, waiting for the next vessel to awaken.

The first resonance had been completed. The second was within reach. But in the shadows of the floating towers, unknown forces were already moving. Not all allies were willing, and not all who sought the Circuit did so with good intentions.

The path forward promised revelations, challenges, and betrayals. The awakening had begun, and Devansh and Kaelani were no longer just wanderers—they were guardians of something older than the world itself.

The twin moons rose high, casting their silver light across the Ember Plains, and in that glow, the shard pulsed with certainty: the next chapter of the Circuit’s memory was about to unfold.

Chapter Five: The Floating Libraries of Dharvalis

At dawn, Devansh and Kaelani began their descent from the Ember Plains toward the valley of mirrored lakes. The shard pulsed with urgent rhythm, almost dragging them forward. Across the expanse, the floating towers of Dharvalis hovered silently, suspended by anti-gravitic fields and shimmering in the pale light of the twin moons. Each tower was carved from crystal and black obsidian, forming lattices of knowledge that defied conventional physics.

“The libraries float to protect themselves,” Kaelani explained, her voice reverent. “Only those aligned with the Grid’s memory can enter without disruption.”

Devansh scanned the horizon. “Then Ishara has already felt the resonance. She’s been chosen.”

Kaelani nodded. “Yes—but the Council may try to claim her first. We need to move fast.”

They approached the base of the valley, where a narrow obsidian bridge stretched across a mirrored lake. The water below reflected not only their forms but also flickers of the Grid’s memory—visions of vessels past, circuits long forgotten, and cities buried beneath sand and time.

Halfway across, the shard pulsed violently. Kaelani froze, sensing a presence. From the lake rose a Council enforcer drone, a sleek, silver machine with limbs like coiled serpents. Its eyes glowed red, scanning for the awakened vessels.

“Run!” Devansh shouted.

They sprinted, but the drone’s speed surpassed human limits. Kaelani held up the shard; it emitted a blinding flash, momentarily halting the drone. Sparks flew as the machine recalibrated, its eyes locking onto them again.

“Hold on,” she yelled, grabbing Devansh’s hand. The shard pulsed, generating a small anti-gravitic field beneath their feet. Together, they lifted off the bridge, skimming above the mirrored water, dodging the drone’s metallic tendrils.

The shard guided them, pulsing faster as the towers of Dharvalis drew near.

Upon reaching the first floating tower, Devansh felt a strange sensation—gravity itself resisting his movements. Kaelani adjusted the shard’s angle, and the pulse stabilized, allowing them to ascend safely.

Inside, the tower was a labyrinth of crystal staircases and rotating knowledge nodes, each containing holographic archives of the Federation’s history, ancient pre-Zyanan civilizations, and sequences of the Ananta Grid. Devansh marveled at the precision of the architecture: circuits embedded within walls, pulsing with faint energy.

“This place isn’t just a library,” he murmured. “It’s a node, like the Grid itself.”

Kaelani led him toward a central chamber. There, hovering over a crystalline desk, was Ishara, her hair braided with silver threads, eyes scanning holographic pages. She paused, sensing the shard’s resonance, and looked up.

“You’re Devansh and Kaelani,” she said calmly. “The Grid called me. I’ve seen the visions.”

Kaelani stepped forward. “You’re the second vessel. The Circuit needs your memory to awaken fully.”

Ishara nodded. “I know. But the Council will arrive. They’ll try to claim the shard—and us.”

Devansh felt a thrill of fear. “Then we need to prepare. The resonance can guide us, but we need strategy.”

Before they could discuss further, a loud vibration shook the tower. The drone from the mirrored lake had arrived, reinforced by Council enforcers descending from anti-gravitic ships. Red light filled the chamber as the drones surged forward.

Kaelani raised the shard, and it responded instantly, creating a barrier of pulsing energy. Ishara stepped closer, placing her hands on a node of the tower. Her touch activated the library’s defense system: rotating staircases shifted to block the drones, and holographic illusions distorted their path.

“Focus the resonance together!” Kaelani shouted.

Devansh took a deep breath, placing his hands over the shard. He felt the Grid’s memory thrumming through him, linking with Kaelani and Ishara. Light expanded, forming a dome that pushed the drones back. The shard pulsed violently, projecting visions of the other vessels, guiding them toward alignment.

The enforcers hesitated, unprepared for this combined resonance. In that moment, Ishara spoke words Devansh had never heard but instinctively understood—an ancient Vaanic invocation that stabilized the field.

The drones faltered, sparks flying as they shut down temporarily. The chamber was safe, for now.

Breathing heavily, Ishara studied the shard. “We’ve activated the second resonance,” she said. “But there’s a pattern emerging. The Circuit isn’t just awakening—it’s testing us. Each vessel must align perfectly, or the Grid may reject us.”

Kaelani looked out a crystalline window. The auroras above Dharvalis had shifted into a spiral, pointing toward the northern horizon. “The third vessel lies there,” she said. “Past the Obsidian Canopies, a city built entirely from living metal. But it’s far, and the Council knows we’re moving.”

Devansh clenched his fists. “Then we leave at first light. Together. And no mistakes.”

Ishara nodded, her calm determination anchoring them. “The sequence continues. We must gather all vessels before the awakening—or the Grid will act on its own.”

Outside, the twin moons reflected on the floating towers, the shard’s light pulsing in perfect harmony with the auroras. A sense of purpose settled over them: the first resonance completed, the second aligned. Seven vessels remained, seven paths intertwined with destiny, and the Circuit waited.

The Council would not rest. Neither could they.

Chapter Six: The Obsidian Canopies

The morning sun barely touched the floating towers of Dharvalis before Devansh, Kaelani, and Ishara launched toward the northern horizon. The auroras above spiraled in anticipation, casting streaks of violet and gold across the mirrored lakes below. The shard pulsed like a heartbeat, guiding them toward the Obsidian Canopies, a city unlike any they had seen—a metropolis grown from living metal, its streets and towers pulsating with bioluminescent veins, reshaping themselves constantly.

Kaelani skimmed over the winds, shard in hand, while Devansh calculated their trajectory. Ishara’s hands hovered over the shard, attuning it to the resonance of the Circuit. Together, they formed a triad, synchronized with the Grid in a way that made even the twin moons feel still.

“This city isn’t static,” Ishara warned. “The Canopies adapt to intruders. If the Council follows, they won’t reach the center.”

Devansh nodded. “Then we use that. Let it work in our favor.”

As they approached, the Obsidian Canopies revealed its true nature. The metal streets rippled like water, buildings shifted direction, and luminous bridges appeared and disappeared with a rhythm almost alive. From below, tendrils of living metal reached upward, reacting to their approach. The shard flared, and Kaelani felt it pulling her along a specific path, leading them closer to the third vessel.

“This is incredible,” Devansh murmured. “It’s as if the city itself recognizes the vessels.”

Ishara frowned. “Or it recognizes the Grid. We must tread carefully. One misstep could trigger defensive protocols. The city doesn’t forgive mistakes.”

They landed on a bridge of woven metal, stretching above a river of molten alloys. From the shadows, a figure emerged—a young man with dark, copper-tinted skin, eyes gleaming with cyan light. His movements were fluid, almost gliding over the shifting ground.

“You’ve come,” he said, voice calm but resonant, echoing slightly as if amplified by the living metal. “I’ve felt the pulse of the Grid for cycles, waiting for the vessels.”

Kaelani stepped forward. “You must be the third vessel.”

He nodded. “I am Rihan. The Obsidian Canopies have guided me here. But you must understand—the Council is already inside. They know of our arrival.”

The Grid’s memory had become a living network, integrating the past, present, and potential futures into a single, evolving consciousness.

Kaelen observed the molten rivers of the Crimson Deltas. “Every phenomenon we’ve guided now understands restraint, autonomy, and cooperation. They can continue evolving independently while remaining aligned with the Grid’s intent.”

Elyra placed her hand over the shard. “We’ve created a world capable of learning from itself, growing without destruction, and remembering harmony as its core principle. This is the ultimate evolution of memory and life.”

Rihan’s voice was quiet, awe-struck. “And you—the nine vessels—are now eternally linked to this memory. Your intent, your guidance, and your choices are embedded within the Grid itself. You are its stewards, its guardians, and its architects of the future.”

Kaelani exhaled, eyes shining. “The world has awakened. The Grid has remembered itself. And we… we have ensured it will continue to grow, evolve, and guide life in harmony.”

Devansh looked at the shard, its glow calm and infinite. “This is only the beginning. The future is alive, dynamic, and self-sustaining. Our role is no longer to control, but to observe, guide when necessary, and protect the balance we’ve established.”

Sahira smiled, gazing at the auroras above. “The anomalies, the ecosystems, the sentient formations—they are now teachers, reminders, and guardians of harmony. The world itself will remember what we’ve created, and the Grid will ensure that memory endures.”

Above the Eternal Peaks, auroras flowed like rivers of light, pulsing with the memory of every region, every anomaly, every conscious system. The Grid, fully awakened, alive, and aware, now guided a world that had learned balance, evolution, and harmony.

Devansh, Kaelani, Ishara, Nivara, Aryon, Sahira, Kaelen, Tavren, and Elyra stood together, hands joined, knowing their journey had reshaped the world forever. The Council had been defeated, not by destruction, but by guidance, alignment, and the evolution of consciousness.

The shard pulsed one final time in their presence, a heartbeat that echoed across the continents. The Grid’s memory had been solidified. The anomalies, the ecosystems, and the semi-sentient formations would continue to evolve independently, guided by harmony, and forever connected to the legacy of the nine vessels.

Devansh whispered, almost to himself, “The world is alive. The Grid remembers. And we… will be remembered as the ones who awakened it.”

Auroras shimmered across the sky, the memory of the world fully alive, and the future—boundless, dynamic, and harmonious—awaited all who would follow in the Grid’s ever-evolving path.

अनन्त परिपथ 
अध्याय एक: शार्दुल का आकाश

ज़्याना संघ की राजधानी शार्दुल के ऊपर का आसमान अजीबोगरीब प्रभामंडलों से जगमगा रहा था। सौर हवाओं से पैदा होने वाली नहीं, बल्कि एक कृत्रिम परिघटना—झिलमिलाती रोशनी की रेखाएँ, मानो किसी विशाल करघे के धागे, खुद को वास्तविकता से बुन रहे हों।

काउंसिल स्पायर की सबसे ऊँची बालकनी से, युवा इंजीनियर देवांश राउत आकाश को निहार रहे थे। ये ऑरोरा लगभग एक दशक पहले, अनंत ग्रिड के आविष्कार के बाद प्रकट हुए थे—एक ग्रहीय ऊर्जा जालक जो ब्रह्मांड की धड़कनों को पकड़ता था। ज़्याना के शासकों ने इसे अभाव के अंत और स्वर्ण युग की नींव के रूप में सराहा था।

लेकिन देवांश ने, राजनेताओं के उलट, गहरे आँकड़ों को पढ़ लिया था। ग्रिड सिर्फ़ ऊर्जा ही नहीं सोख रहा था; वह कुछ और भी संग्रहीत कर रहा था। पैटर्न। यादें। फुसफुसाहटें।

उसकी दादी उसे सोते समय नव-कथाओं की कहानियाँ सुनाया करती थीं—समय से पहले की सभ्यताओं की कहानियाँ, जो विचारों को पदार्थ में बदल सकती थीं, कुम्हारों द्वारा बुनी गई मिट्टी की तरह ब्रह्मांड बुन सकती थीं। बचपन में वह उन पर हँसता था, लेकिन अब, ग्रिड की झिलमिलाहट को देखते हुए, उसे लगा कि उसके शब्द फिर से साँस ले रहे हैं।

परिषद बेचैन थी। बाज़ारों में अफ़वाहें फैल रही थीं: लोग एक जैसे सपने देख रहे थे, अजनबी लोग अपने मन में एक जैसे वाक्यों के साथ जाग रहे थे— “सर्किट को याद है।” कुछ लोगों ने दावा किया कि उन्हें शहर के जनरेटरों की गड़गड़ाहट में आवाज़ें सुनाई दे रही थीं।

देवांश कोई रहस्यवादी नहीं था। वह ग्रिड के सबसे नए नोड्स में से एक, कलाराष्ट्र ऐरे का प्रमुख वास्तुकार था। उसकी टीम ने इसे खारे रेगिस्तानों के नीचे, जहाँ प्राचीन विवर्तनिक निशान एक प्राकृतिक प्रवर्धक का निर्माण करते थे, बनाया था। इस ऐरे का उद्देश्य दक्षता को दस गुना बढ़ाना था। फिर भी, सक्रियण की उसी रात, उसने कुछ असंभव सुना—जैसे किसी भूली-बिसरी भाषा में कोई मंत्र, मशीनरी में धड़क रहा हो।

"सपने लीक हो रहे हैं," उनके सहकर्मी प्रियम ने एक बार मज़ाक में बुदबुदाया था। लेकिन देवांश ने जितना ज़्यादा विश्लेषण किया, उसे उतना ही शक हुआ कि यह सच है। ग्रिड सिर्फ़ ऊर्जा ही नहीं खींच रहा था—वह किसी विशाल चीज़ की चेतना को खोद रहा था।

शहर से दूर सूर्या गेट के अंडरमार्केट में एक और नाटक सामने आया।

केलानी नाम की एक लड़की, फटे हुए लाल रेशमी कपड़ों में लिपटी, भीड़ के बीच किसी भूत की तरह चल रही थी। उसका कोई उपनाम नहीं था, न ही कोई मूल, जिसकी पुष्टि कोई कर सके। कुछ लोगों का कहना था कि वह वेयरा की खनन बस्तियों में पैदा हुई थी, तो कुछ का कहना था कि वह रेगिस्तानी तूफ़ानों से रेंगकर निकली थी। लेकिन जो बात उसे सबसे ज़्यादा प्रभावित करती थी, वह थी उसकी आँखें—जिनकी पुतलियाँ सुनहरे रंग की थीं, और जब भी वह किसी मशीन को छूती, तो हल्की-सी चमक उठती।

कैलानी एक तस्कर थी, टूटी हुई तकनीक की मरम्मत करने वाली, और खोई हुई चीज़ों को ढूँढ़ने वाली। आज रात, उसके मुवक्किल ने कुछ अनोखा माँगा था: एक अनंत शार्ड।

किसी भी साधारण व्यक्ति के पास ऐसा टुकड़ा नहीं होना चाहिए था। हर टुकड़ा एक क्रिस्टल नोड था, ग्रिड के टुकड़े, जो असंभव शक्ति से गुंजायमान थे। परिषद ने उन्हें बंद कर दिया, लेकिन सूर्य द्वार में, नियम पिघले हुए काँच की तरह झुक गए।

जैसे ही वह एक मसाले की दुकान के पास से गुज़री, भुनी हुई दाल की टिकियों की खुशबू ऊपर से आधे टूटे ड्रोनों की ओज़ोन के साथ मिल गई। उसका हाथ कमर पर रखे थैले से टकराया—उसके अंदर का टुकड़ा गर्मी से धड़क उठा। ऊर्जा भंडार जैसा नहीं। बल्कि दिल की धड़कन जैसा।

उसके ग्राहक ने इसके लिए एक बड़ी रकम देने का वादा किया था। लेकिन रात में उस टुकड़े ने उसे फुसफुसाकर बताया। उसने सपना देखा कि प्रकाश की विशाल नदियाँ, विशालकाय प्राणी, आधे मशीन, आधे विचार, पहेलियाँ बोलते हुए। उसने देवांश का चेहरा देखा, हालाँकि वह उससे कभी नहीं मिली थी, औरोरा में घिरा हुआ।

ज़्याना के अंदर कुछ हलचल हो रही थी।

परिषद शिखर पर वापस आकर, सत्तारूढ़ मंत्रियों की बहस के दौरान, कक्ष बड़बड़ाहट से भर गया। भारी आवाज़ और लोहे जैसी दाढ़ी वाले मंत्री त्रिकाल ने गरजते हुए कहा,

"ग्रिड स्थिर है। हम अफ़वाहों को फैलने नहीं दे सकते... आवाज़ें। इससे जनता का विश्वास डगमगा जाएगा।"

“लेकिन डेटा-” देवांश ने शुरू किया, लेकिन उसे घूर कर चुप करा दिया गया।

परिषद को डेटा नहीं चाहिए था। वे नियंत्रण चाहते थे।

फिर भी, उसके पास एक ऐसा राज़ था जो उनमें से किसी को भी नहीं पता था: तीन दिन पहले, उसके सिस्टम ने ग्रिड से एक संदेश पकड़ा था। यह कोई बेतरतीब स्थिर संदेश नहीं था। लय में दोहराए जा रहे प्रतीकों का एक क्रम था। उसने इसका अनुवाद प्राचीन वानिक लिपि में किया था, जो बहुत पहले ही लुप्त हो चुकी थी और अर्ध-पौराणिक। संदेश बेहद सरल था:

"सर्किट बारह चक्रों में जागृत होगा। बर्तन तैयार करो।"

देवांश को "वाहिकाओं" का मतलब नहीं पता था। लेकिन उसकी हर सहज बुद्धि उसे बता रही थी: यह कोई खराबी नहीं थी। यह तो इरादा था।

उस रात, बेचैन, देवांश सादे वस्त्र पहने निचले इलाकों में भटकता रहा। उसे परिषद के घेरे से बाहर आवाज़ें चाहिए थीं। वह सूर्य द्वार में पहुँच गया, जहाँ नीऑन की चमक मिट्टी की दीवारों को आग और छाया के रंगों से रंग रही थी।

और वहाँ, बाज़ार के किनारे पर, उसका रास्ता कैलानी से टकरा गया।

सचमुच। उसका पीछा किया जा रहा था—काले कवच पहने तीन सिपाही, उसे रुकने के लिए चिल्ला रहे थे। वह एक गली में घुसी, देवांश से टकराई, और एक पल के लिए उनकी आँखें मिल गईं। उसकी तीखी, गणना करती हुई निगाहें उसकी सुनहरी, अप्राकृतिक पुतलियों से टकराईं।

समय ठहर गया.

उसकी थैली में, वह टुकड़ा भड़क उठा, और ठीक उसी क्षण, शार्दुल के ऊपर की ज्योतियाँ हिल गईं, मानो किसी अशांत तालाब में लहरें उठ रही हों। शहर में एक गहरा कंपन छा गया, हल्का लेकिन नकारा नहीं जा सका।

“तुम्हारे पास क्या है?” देवांश ने धीमी लेकिन जरूरी आवाज में पूछा।

केलानी मुस्कुराई, जबकि क़दमों की आहट नज़दीक आ रही थी। "कुछ ऐसा जो तुम्हारी परिषद ने खो दिया। या शायद कुछ ऐसा जो उन्होंने कभी समझा ही नहीं।"

इससे पहले कि वह जवाब दे पाता, पुलिसवाले कोने में आ गए। उसने उसकी कलाई पकड़ ली। "जवाब चाहिए तो आ जाओ।"

हर तार्किक प्रवृत्ति के विरुद्ध, देवांश ने उसका अनुसरण किया।

शहर की दीवारों के पार, नमक के रेगिस्तानी तारों के नीचे, कैलानी ने उस टुकड़े को प्रकट किया। देवांश की साँस अटक गई। वह क्रिस्टल निष्क्रिय नहीं था—वह जीवित था, जिसमें छोटी आकाशगंगाएँ ढह रही थीं और पुनर्जन्म ले रही थीं, जैसे भग्न पैटर्न झिलमिला रहे हों।

"यह मुझे बुला रहा है," कैलानी फुसफुसाई। "जैसे यह मुझे जानता हो। जैसे यह इंतज़ार कर रहा हो।"

देवांश ने हाथ बढ़ाया। जैसे ही उसकी उंगलियाँ उसकी सतह पर लगीं, वह टुकड़ा गूँज उठा—ध्वनि में नहीं, बल्कि दृश्यों में। उसने रेगिस्तान के नीचे दबा एक विशाल मशीन-मंदिर देखा, जो ज़्याना से भी पुराना था। उसने प्रकाश के प्राणियों को, मांस में उकेरे गए परिपथों को, एक शाश्वत अभिलेखागार में चलते हुए देखा। और उसने एक ही वाक्य सुना:

“सर्किट अपने जहाजों की तलाश कर रहा है।”

वह लड़खड़ाते हुए पीछे हट गया, हाँफते हुए। कैलानी की आँखें पहले से कहीं ज़्यादा चमक उठीं, उस पर टिकी हुई।

“तुमने भी देखा है,” वह धीरे से बोली।

ऊपर की ओर औरोरा तेजी से घूमते हुए घूम रहे थे, मानो आकाश ने उनके संपर्क पर प्रतिक्रिया व्यक्त की हो।

पहली बार, देवांश को सच्चाई का एहसास हुआ: ग्रिड मानवता की रचना नहीं थी। यह किसी प्राचीन चीज़ का स्मृति इंजन था, और यह जाग रहा था।

और किसी तरह, वह और यह रहस्यमय लड़की इसके डिजाइन में उलझ गए।

अध्याय दो: फुसफुसाता रेगिस्तान

शार्दुल के पूर्व में रेगिस्तान जुड़वाँ चंद्रमाओं के नीचे चाँदी के समुद्र की तरह फैला हुआ था। कभी बंजर और बेजान, ये टीले अब प्रकाश की धारियों से मंद-मंद स्पंदित हो रहे थे—ये नीचे गहरे दबे अनंत ग्रिड से आने वाली प्रतिध्वनियाँ थीं। बड़े-बुज़ुर्ग इस घटना को प्रकाशरेखा , यानी प्रकाश रेखाएँ कहते थे। व्यापारी रात में इस क्षेत्र में आने से बचते थे, उनका दावा था कि जो लोग चमकती रेत के पीछे बहुत दूर तक चले जाते थे, वे कभी-कभी गायब हो जाते थे और पीछे सिर्फ़ अपने पैरों के निशान छोड़ जाते थे।

देवांश कैलानी के बगल में टहल रहा था, उसकी परिषद की पोशाकें एक खुरदुरे यात्री के लबादे के नीचे छिपी हुई थीं। उसका मन अविश्वास से भर गया। उसने हज़ारों ग्रिड नोड्स देखे थे और अनगिनत सर्किटों का निरीक्षण किया था, लेकिन वह जो टुकड़ा ले जा रही थी, वह ज़्याना के वास्तुकारों द्वारा डिज़ाइन किए गए किसी भी टुकड़े से बिल्कुल अलग था।

यह एक जीवित अंग की तरह गुनगुना रहा था।

"मुझे बताओ कि तुमने इसे कहाँ से चुराया है," उसने अंततः कहा, उसका स्वर अपेक्षा से अधिक तीखा था।

कैलानी ने उसे तिरछी नज़र से देखा, उसकी सुनहरी आँखें चाँदनी में हल्की-सी चमक रही थीं। "चोरी नहीं हुई। मिली। वेयरान खदानों के नीचे एक खंडहर में। एक ऐसी जगह जिसका नक्शा बनाने की हिम्मत किसी खनिक ने नहीं की। कहा जाता था कि यह शापित है, लेकिन मैंने... मैंने इसे पुकारते सुना।"

देवांश ने मुट्ठियाँ भींच लीं। खदानों के नीचे खंडहर? परिषद के नक्शों में वहाँ कुछ भी अंकित नहीं था। फिर भी उसके शब्दों ने उसकी स्मृति में दबी किसी चीज़ को झकझोर दिया—एक पुराने शोध पत्र का एक फुटनोट: 'ज़्यानान से पहले के भूमिगत हॉल, जो भूगर्भीय पतन से बंद हो गए थे।'

उन्होंने पूछा, "इसे काले बाज़ार में क्यों लाया जाए?"

"क्योंकि परिषद हर चीज़ जमा करके रखती है। वे कहते हैं कि ग्रिड उनका है, लेकिन मुझे लगता है कि शुरू से ही यह हमारा था ही नहीं। और अगर कोई चीज़ जाग रही है, तो वह उनकी इजाज़त नहीं माँगेगी।"

उसकी अवज्ञा ने उसे बेचैन कर दिया। वह हमेशा से मानता था कि परिषद में खामियाँ हैं, लेकिन ज़रूरी है। उसे इतनी खुलकर बोलते सुनना मानो वर्जित अग्नि का स्वाद चखना हो।

वे बेसाल्ट की एक चट्टान पर पहुँचे, जहाँ चमकती रेत प्रकाश की नदियों की तरह एक दूसरे से मिल रही थी। कैलानी घुटनों के बल बैठी और उसने उस टुकड़े को ज़मीन पर रख दिया। तुरंत, रेगिस्तान ने प्रतिक्रिया दी—नसें चमक उठीं, चमक के धागे बाहर की ओर दौड़ पड़े।

देवांश की साँस अटक गई। "आप सीधे ग्रिड से जुड़ रहे हैं," उसने फुसफुसाते हुए कहा। "बिना कंसोल के, बिना ऐरे के..."

टुकड़ा फिर धड़का, और देवांश के मन में एक दृश्य उभर आया। एक विशाल कक्ष, जो घाटी जैसा था, जिसे इंसानी औज़ारों से नहीं, बल्कि किसी ऐसी चीज़ ने गढ़ा था जो समझ से परे थी। क्रिस्टल की दीवारें आंकड़ों से धड़क रही थीं, मानो कोई दिल युगों से धड़क रहा हो। और उसके बीच में, नौ सिंहासन खाली, प्रतीक्षा में खड़े थे।

जब दृश्य धुंधला गया, तो देवांश काँप उठा। कैलानी ने उसे संभाला, रात की ठंड के बावजूद उसका स्पर्श गर्म था।

“तुमने देखा था,” वह धीरे से बोली।

उसने भारी आवाज़ में सिर हिलाया, "नौ सिंहासन। बर्तन..."

उसके होंठों पर एक गंभीर मुस्कान आ गई। "तो फिर तुम और मैं एक ही सपना देख रहे हैं।"

दूर, काउंसिल स्पायर में अलार्म बज उठा। मंत्री त्रिकाल अपने सहयोगियों के साथ भागते हुए, कमान कक्ष में घुस गए।

"कलाराष्ट्र ऐरे में उछाल की सूचना है," एक तकनीशियन हकलाते हुए बोला। "रेगिस्तान के चतुर्भुजों में ऊर्जा प्रवाह तेज़ी से बढ़ रहा है। इसका कोई ज्ञात कारण नहीं है।"

त्रिकाल की आँखें सिकुड़ गईं, “और इंजीनियर राउत?”

"मंत्री जी, उनका आवास खाली है। पिछले परिषद सत्र के बाद से वे नहीं आए हैं।"

त्रिकाल ने मेज़ पर ज़ोर से मुक्का मारा। "उसे ढूँढ़ो। अगर अनुनाद भंग की अफ़वाह फैली, तो संघ में हड़कंप मच जाएगा। और अगर वह गुंडा बन गया..." उसकी निगाहें लोहे की तरह सख्त हो गईं। "...उसे चुप करा दिया जाएगा।"

रेगिस्तान में वापस आकर, कैलानी देवांश को रेत से आधी दबी एक दरार की ओर ले गई। वह अंदर झुकी, दीवारों पर बनी प्राचीन नक्काशी पर टॉर्च की रोशनी टिमटिमा रही थी। लिपि ज़्यानन नहीं थी, फिर भी देवांश ने वानिक की प्रतिध्वनियाँ पहचान लीं—वही प्रतीक जो ग्रिड ने कुछ दिन पहले प्रसारित किए थे।

“इसमें क्या लिखा है?” कैलानी ने पूछा।

उसने काँपती उँगलियों से एक का पता लगाया। " 'सर्किट बनाया नहीं जाता। इसे याद रखा जाता है।' "

उसकी भौंहें सिकुड़ गईं। “याद आया... किसने?”

उसने बड़ी मुश्किल से निगला। "अपने आप से। या उनसे जो पहले आए थे।"

वे तब तक और नीचे उतरे जब तक सुरंग चौड़ी होकर एक कक्ष में तब्दील नहीं हो गई। उसके बीच में काले पत्थर का एक चबूतरा खड़ा था, जो फटा और झुलसा हुआ था। उस पर एक आधा टूटा हुआ गोला रखा था, जो हल्की चमक रहा था।

कैलानी श्रद्धा से पास आई। "यहीं पर मुझे वह टुकड़ा मिला था। कभी यह इसी का हिस्सा था।"
